documents.document: Bearing in mind that America has been at war 93% of the time: 222 out of 239 years since 1776.
It is time that our politicians re-evaluate what future contributions it is reasonable for us to make in respect of this alliance.
Considering that the Coalition government in Australia have led us into three wars, contrary to International Law and U.N. resolutions.
or contrary to our national security interests, he should be held accountable for it.
The quid pro quo must be watched, and if Turnbull gives away something that is vital to Australia's national interests,
What will it be? Sending our young men and women into a Syrian or other conflict?
If Trump gets Turnbull out of a political jam, then he will expect something from Turnbull (Australia) in return.
Trump is a transaction President. He does and expects others to do deals.
The really serious issue here, is what is the quid pro quo?
There is a lot of talk in Australia about Trump yelling at Turnbull (or Mr. Tumble). My view is "who cares".
More tomorrow.
Sea surface temperatures on the edge of the ice are also running well above normal in many places, further inhibiting sea ice growth.
Compounding the warm air is warm water.
said Jennifer Francis, a climate scientist at Rutgers University who studies the Arctic.
"The ridiculously warm temperatures in the Arctic during October and November this year are off the charts over our 68 years of measurements
In other words, it was so warm in the Arctic that despite the lack of sunlight, sea ice actually disappeared.
further slowing Arctic sea ice growth and even turning it around for a few days.
The oddness continued into November. A large area of the Arctic saw temperatures as much as 36°F above normal,
By the end of the month, the Arctic was missing a chunk of ice the size of the eastern U.S.
Temperatures stayed stuck in their September range, pausing sea ice growth.
The latest twist in the Arctic sea ice saga began in mid-October.
"I've never seen anything like it this last year and half," Mark Serreze, director of the National Snow and Ice Data Center, said.
what's happening in the Arctic right now stands out for just how outlandish it is.
the hottest year on record set three years in a row, global coral bleaching entering a third year — the norm,
Even in an age where climate change is making outliers — lowest maximum sea ice extent set two years in a row,
This follows the previous winter, when temperatures saw a huge December spike.
Intense warmth in both the air and oceans is driving the mini-meltdown at a time when Arctic sea ice should be rapidly growing.
Sea ice growth slowed to a crawl and even started shrinking for a bit.
But in the depths of the polar night, a strange thing started to happen in mid-October.
Usually that serves as a cue for sea ice to spread its frozen tentacles across the Arctic Ocean.
The sun set on the North Pole months ago, not to rise again until spring.
i.e. as much as 30°C or 54°F warmer than in 1979-2000.
temperatures over much of the Arctic Ocean were at the top end of the scale that day,
While the Arctic as a whole was as much as 3.34°C or 6.01°F warmer than in 1979-2000 on December 22, 2016,
Within the Arctic, the Arctic Ocean is warming most rapidly.
To some degree what IS happening in the Arctic is driving global warming over the whole world.
Strange things are happening in the Arctic now.
And a big portion of it came from just five glaciers, about which scientists now have more cause to worry than ever.
suggests that the Greenland ice sheet lost a whopping 1 trillion tonnes of ice between the years 2011 and 2014 alone.
A satellite study, published recently in the journal Geophysical Research Letters,
More than 40 percent melted last year.
This suggests more and more of the sea ice is melting every year. The Greenland ice sheet continues its dramatic melting.
By contrast, in the 1980s, about 20 percent of the sea ice was old and about 45 percent had formed that year.
said Kit Kovacs, a senior scientist at the Norwegian Polar Institute.
with only 3 percent of the ice considered old, meaning it had been around for more than four years,
On the day when ice reached its maximum in 2015, 70 percent had formed in the previous year,
was the lowest since 1979, when record keeping began.
In addition, the sea ice extent during the summer months (the Sun doesn't shine there in the winter)
The average air temperature above Arctic land represents a 5.4-degree-F (3 degrees C) increase from the average air temperatures in 1900.
The Arctic is getting warmer wetter and weirder.
If and when this happens, the West Antarctic ice sheet would also likely to show irreversible melting.
Once global warming pushes the melting process past that line, it begins to perpetuate itself."
Prof. Sergei Kirpotin, a botanist at Russia's Tomsk State University, says: "There's a critical barrier...
The West Siberian bog is estimated to contain 70 billion tonnes of CO2.
triggering the release of methane, a greenhouse gas twenty times more powerful than CO2, from thick layers of thawing peat.
As the Arctic continue to warm, melting permafrost in the boreal forests and further north in the Arctic tundra is now starting to melt,
"We know this is due to climate change (human-induced)."
in a press briefing at the annual meeting of the American Geophysical Union.
said Rick Spinrad, the chief scientific officer a the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA),
"Warming is happening more than twice as fast in the Arctic than anywhere else in the world,"
And more than half of the Greenland ice sheet melted in 2015.
and sea ice extent was at an all-time low since record keeping began in 1979.
2015 was the warmest on record for the Arctic (until 2016 came along which blew all previous records away)
The Arctic is warming at an unprecedented rate, new research suggests.
Nowhere can the effects of global warming be more acutely felt than in the Arctic.
Either way, what they say should be dismissed.
is either stupid, or deliberately arguing the contrary view for reasons of their own.
Anyone who says that such a powerful correlation does not so strongly suggest causality to the point that it cannot be credibly denied
This increase in CO2 has already caused a substantial rise in temperature.
and can be well accounted for based on the simple premise that about 60 percent of fossil-fuel emissions stay in the air.
This recent relentless rise in CO2 shows a remarkably constant relationship with fossil-fuel burning,
In 2013, CO2 levels surpassed 400 ppm for the first time in recorded history.
During ice ages, CO2 levels were around 200 parts per million (ppm), and during the warmer interglacial periods, they hovered around 280 ppm
Levels of carbon dioxide (CO2) in the atmosphere are higher than they have been at any time in the past 400,000 years.
We have dramatically increased the level of carbon dioxide in the atmosphere.
and methane levels have increased 148 percent.
Since the Industrial Revolution began in about 1750, carbon dioxide levels have increased nearly 38 percent as of 2009
mostly by burning fossil fuels, but also from cutting down carbon-absorbing forests.
humans have been artificially raising the concentration of greenhouse gases in the atmosphere at an ever-increasing rate,
What has scientists concerned now is that over the past 250 years
Temperatures are certain to go up further.
and the rate of temperature increase has nearly doubled in the last 50 years.
The global average surface temperature rose 0.6 to 0.9 degrees Celsius (1.1 to 1.6° F) between 1906 and 2005,
primarily due to the greenhouse gases released as people burn fossil fuels.
Global warming is the unusually rapid increase in Earth’s average surface temperature over the past century
Answering these questions is perhaps the most significant scientific challenge of our time.
How much more will the Earth warm? How will Earth respond?
How can we be certain that human-released greenhouse gases are causing the warming?
How does this warming compare to previous changes in Earth’s climate?
But in the past century, another force has started to influence Earth’s climate: humanity.
as the atmosphere or surface changed, or when the Sun’s energy varied.
Climate has changed when the planet received more or less sunlight due to subtle shifts in its orbit,
Throughout its long history, Earth has warmed and cooled time and again.
Global warming. It is very serious.
What they get is slogans.
No wonder people turn away from traditional politics. After 30 years of stagnant wages and declining standards of living, they want change.
and I suspect it means as much as the one from their opponents: "jobs and growth", and that is precisely nothing.
but alas, we have an ALP which has exchanged its high Labor traditions for populist slogans, like "jobs, jobs, jobs" whatever that means,
If we had a Labor opposition worth having, it would oppose committing young Australians to fight in such wars of Imperialism,
The Middle East is a quagmire where great powers are vying for control of oil and gas reserves
